content.text: While lying on their belly, babies move forward by pulling themselves with one elbow and pushing the diagonal leg alternately, switching again and again.

Working with both one arm and the diagonal leg together to create movement increases the number of connections between nerves in the brain, creating more and more connections between the left and right hemispheres. This improves coordination.
At this stage, your baby’s levels of curiosity and independence increase with the ability to explore more of their surroundings.

If you see that your baby is having a hard time achieving this milestone by the age of 8 months, you should consult with your pediatrician or an infant development guide to learn how to help your baby. These important abilities are the foundation of their physical, sensory and emotional needs. Here are some signs that your baby may need help:

ul: Army crawling with only one arm and leg and not switching between sides.
Crawling with only the hands, without moving the legs at all.
Crawling with only the legs, without moving the hands at all.
Crawling like a worm, meaning lying on the belly with legs straight on the floor, pushing with arms and feet and falling forward on their belly.
Most kids do not army crawl. Instead, they move directly to a regular crawl because they don’t have the ability to create this movement!
